questions.question: I met ………………………. pretty girl there.
questions.description: We use a here because the listener does not know which girl we are talking about.

questions.question: It is …………………………. interesting movie.
questions.description: We use ‘an’ here because the reader /listener does not know which movie we are talking about.

questions.question: …………………………. child is playing with his toys.
questions.description: We use the here because we are talking about a particular child.

questions.question: She is ………………………….. finest actor I have ever seen.
Can you see …………………………. cat over there?
questions.description: Either could be used here with slightly different meanings.

questions.question: She wants to be ……………………… architect.
questions.description: A/an is often used to mean one.

questions.question: There is …………………………… spider on the roof.
questions.description: A/an is often used to mean one.

questions.question: Rich people must help ……………………………….
questions.description: The poor means all poor people.

questions.question: She has ………………………….. mole on her right arm.
………………………….. train arrives at
questions.description: We are talking about a particular train here.

questions.question: If you are not feeling well, you should consult ………………………… doctor.
questions.description: Either could be used here with slightly different meaning. If we use ‘the’ it means that the listener knows which doctor we are talking about.

questions.question: He is seeing …………………………… French girl.
questions.description: The speaker does not say which French girl they are talking about. Hence, we use 'a' here.
